Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Mapping Changes in the Active Stream Channel Network in Mesoscale Watersheds in order to Understand Distinct Signatures in Event Recession Curves
Award.AbstractNarration:
Water flow in watersheds is most often studied by either measuring stream flow at the watershed outlet or by making point measurements in wells within the watershed. Neither is adequate for gaining a complete picture of watershed function because measurements at the outlet can be too broad and point measurements too localized. This project seeks to fill the knowledge gap by mapping the expansion and contraction of active stream channels throughout the watershed and providing insights into which areas of a watershed are or are not contributing flow to the watershed outlet. This will provide new knowledge for better understanding how water, soil, and chemicals move through watersheds and how stream discharge will change, particularly during periods of little precipitation. As an education and outreach effort of this project, the project will develop hands-on learning opportunities for middle and high school science students and help train graduate students.

Pairs of observed rates of stream flow decline after rainfall ends (i.e. recession flow) and the concurrent stream flow value have long been used in the hydrologic sciences to infer aquifer properties at the watershed scale. However, new work has shown that spatial variation in stream flow source areas across a catchment may explain recession as well or better than aquifer property and hydraulics. Thus, there is an emerging debate on what really controls recession. Resolving this debate can provide fundamental insights into watershed function. To investigate the controls on recession, this project will install high-density sensor networks at up to six medium-sized watersheds at different locations throughout the U.S. to map changes in the extent of the active stream channel network. Sensor measurements of discharge will be supplemented with visual mapping of the active stream network, thermal imaging of likely groundwater inputs to streams, and soil moisture measurements. The project could have broader implications for predicting discharge in ungauged basins and understanding processes of solutes moving through watersheds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In periods of low streamflow, people and ecosystems often either share or compete for water resources.  Therefore, it is important to understand and predict the rate at which streamflow decreases between precipitation events. This depends on the contribution to the stream from both surface water bodies, soil water storage and groundwater aquifers and depletion by plant water use and evaporation. Traditional modelling of groundwater movement to the surface has been based on the Boussinesq equation, which assumes base flow, or streamflow that is derived from persistent, slowly varying water sources equally across the watershed.  This case is generally true where large channels or agricultural tiles drain water from an aquifer near the land surface, often in wide valleys.  For this case the average daily streamflow can be approximately related to the daily decrease in streamflow on a logarithmic chart.  The slope of this line is defined by an exponent which should theoretically remain constant over wide changes in declining streamflow. This approach was popularized by Brutsaert. In practice, the logarithmic line is often not linear, nor of constant slope. 

Recent theory has proposed streamflow contributions are unevenly distributed throughout the landscape. This is most likely the case in hilly settings, where an extensive continuous shallow aquifer is less likely. In this case soil depth, local ponds and bedrock fractures may all have different and independent storage time characteristics.  For example, field observations in Sleepers River, Vermont indicate that that most small streams originate at seeps, springs or wetlands throughout the watershed. This condition is better represented mathematically as one or more linear reservoirs, each with its own time constant. 

The difference between the continuous aquifer drainage and multiple reservoir models are currently an active area of research and require rigorous testing. Oddly, the presented models do not account for precipitation or seasonal changes in plant water use during the recession period.  Where this is sensible is in regions with strongly seasonal precipitation with long dry periods.  This research focused on recession analysis under more challenging conditions, hilly topography with frequent precipitation.  

We asked: 1. How do recession curves depend on data selection methods? One approach is to use only periods of declining streamflow, with limitations on the beginning and end of this period, and another is to use only rain free periods following a rain event. Each method has limitations. The Brutsaert method neglects recession during non-monotonic dry periods. We know that streamflow can be monotonically declining during periods of rainfall due to a variety of factors, and the rain-free method neglects whole-watershed recession that occurs during periods of rain.

 2. How do study area characteristics control the form of recession curves? Selecting and applying one method of recession analysis at several unique watersheds may not be adequate to account for the many ways a natural watershed exhibits the physical processes occurring during a recession. Each of the five watersheds appear exhibited unique recession curves, despite using the same approach within each method.

Counterintuitively, data plots of the rain-free method appear much more chaotic than those for the monotonically declining analysis, and it is difficult to decipher individual recession events. Similarly, recession events selected under the rain-free method are rarely linear, indicating the presence of additional controls on recessions outside of monotonically declining periods. Although most published data are daily average, these measurements are likely too course a time scale to represent recession analysis for streams other than small rivers, for example effects of small scale fluctuations in due to evaporation and transpiration processes. Ultimately, we found that recession characteristics at the point of measurement depend on both the local characteristics at that outlet, and integrated characteristics of the whole watershed.
